1197: Creature Bond.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1197: Creature Bond.text_parsed: Back in the early days of Magic, many cards were printed that didn't exactly fit the color pie as we know it today. Creature Bond was just such a card. This aura has a very black feel to it. Not only does it have a black feel to it, but it would probably have suited black better. Blue's removal tends to send things back to players' hands - not to their graveyards, making this card a bit suboptimal. You could enchant a creature with this and then ping it to death with Prodigal Sorcerers and Pirate Ships, but that probably means the creature has a low toughness, and Creature Bond isn't going to do much damage. Otherwise, you'll have to rely on your big creatures to kill off theirs (Siren's Call might help in this). But Creature Bond is best paired with black and efficient creature removal.

This aura has a very black feel to it.  Not only does it have a black feel to it, but it would probably have suited black better. Otherwise, you'll have to rely on your big creatures to kill off theirs ([autocard]Siren's Call [/autocard]might help in this).  But Creature Bond is best paired with black and efficient creature removal.

1198: Drain Power.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1198: Drain Power.text_parsed: Drain Power is best used in the late game to really load up your mana pool for a big finisher spell. It's not a particularly reliable way to get mana for two reasons: 1.) If your opponent has good tempo, he probably won't have a lot of untapped lands during your turn, and 2.) If your opponent has any mana outlets at all (Dragon Engine, for example), you'll get the bare minimum. Drain Power is more effective for denying your opponent the ability to cast later spells. This is why it's a good combo piece to a finisher spell such as Fireball or Disintegrate. Once you've cast Drain Power, you no longer need to worry about your opponent countering your important spell.

1199: Energy Flux.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1199: Energy Flux.text_parsed: Blue doesn't have a whole lot of artifact removal, but Energy Flux puts a heavy cost on all artifacts. While it isn't a guarantee, and doesn't allow for targeted removal, it puts a huge burden on any deck that relies heavily on artifacts. Mana generating artifacts are mostly neutralized by this enchantment. In Revised, Shatterstorm is the best card for mass artifact destruction, but one could argue that Energy Flux, which stays around turn after turn rather than just wiping out all the artifacts on the battlefield at any given time, is a more lasting protection against artifacts.

1200: Feedback.author: Gaussgoat
1200: Feedback.text_parsed:
Wanderlust for blue. Back in the day, enchantments were quite strong, and this card was absolutely playable. It was a great way to slowly ping someone to death.

Blue actually had a really strong strategy where you could just pepper people with mini-hits every turn until they were dead. Combine this card with Prodigal Sorcerer and Relic Bind and you could dish out a lot of damage.

2.5/5

1200: Feedback.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1200: Feedback.text_parsed: Of all the cycle of upkeep pingers, Feedback is arguably the least useful (though it might have competition from Warp Artifact depending on the play environment). The problem is that not all decks use enchantments. Feedback is fun to play on Circles of Protection and the like, but the best thing I ever did with Feedback was play it on a Blue Ward. I have seen someone play Blue Ward all of ONCE in sixteen years of Magic, and I happened to be holding Feedback in my hand at the time. The Blue Ward, as I recall, was on an Order of Leitbur, and I remember my opponent telling me that I couldn't target the Order since it had protection from blue. I smugly pointed out that I wasn't targeting the Order at all, but the Blue Ward enchanting the Order. The game didn't end so good for me. I'm fairly certain I was pummeled into submission by that very Pro Blue Order of Leitbur well before my Feedback had a change to dish out more than 3 or 4 points of damage.

You can use it in a number of ways - offensively, if the battlefield is clogged up with your opponent's artifacts; defensively, if you want to protect your artifacts from targeted destruction (or even your own Wrath of God type effect); or as a way to replenish your hand to fuel storm or re-use artifacts with "comes onto the battlefield" abilities. But in reference to the flavor text... exactly what has Drafna ever been credited with except for Drafna's Restoration?

1203: Island Fish Jasconius.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1203: Island Fish Jasconius.text_parsed: The idea that Island Fish Jasconius is only "vaguely known by people" is ludicrous in its own right. Island Fish is an iconic piece of Magic history. And while Gopher may be *ahem* overstating the Fish's virtues ever-so-slightly, dropping this on the battlefield when your opponent was playing Pearled Unicorns and Ironroot Treefolk was a gasp-worthy event. Like so many of the early blue behemoths, Island Fish was not without its drawbacks. The 3 blue mana to untap wasn't so bad, considering you had to have 7 mana just to get it out in the first place. But the Fish couldn't even attack unless your opponent had Islands. This made it necessary to run Phantasmal Terrain in your deck, just in case. Players who were all ready using Sea Serpents and/or Lord of Atlantis in their decks probably all ready had those land enchantments in their decks, so the Island Fish was a big, fat upgrade with few negatives.

Like so many of the early blue behemoths, Island Fish was not without its drawbacks. 1204: Jump.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1204: Jump.text_parsed: When I was but a wee Magic player in 1994, I scoffed at Jump. For the exact same cost, I could give my creatures flying permanently with Flight. But Jump provided me with something Flight never could - the element of surprise. Getting attacked by a Serra Angel or Sengir Vampire is never much fun, unless you have a Sea Serpent in play and a Jump in your hand. The real problem with Jump isn't that it isn't useful. It's that it's blue. Most of blue's most useful creatures all ready fly. In a multi-colored blue and green deck, Jump becomes much better.
1204: Jump.text_posted: When I was but a wee Magic player in 1994, I scoffed at [autocard]Jump[/autocard].  For the exact same cost, I could give my creatures flying [i]permanently[/i] with [autocard]Flight[/autocard].  But Jump provided me with something Flight never could - the element of surprise.  Getting attacked by a [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] or [autocard]Sengir Vampire[/autocard] is never much fun, unless you have a [autocard]Sea Serpent[/autocard] in play and a Jump in your hand.  The real problem with Jump isn't that it isn't useful.  It's that it's blue.  Most of blue's most useful creatures all ready fly.  In a multi-colored blue and green deck, Jump becomes much better.

1206: Lord of Atlantis.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1206: Lord of Atlantis.text_parsed: Until the release of Fallen Empires, Merfolk wasn't a very viable deck option, which is unfortunate, because Lord of Atlantis is a solid card. Like Goblin King and Zombie Master, Lord of Atlantis had the unfortunate downside of affecting ALL merfolk in play, and not just your own. Back then, lords didn't bestow their bonuses on one another, which meant the only creatures Lord of Atlantis could pump up within the set was the lowly Merfolk of the Pearl Trident. At least Goblin King had Mons's Goblin Raiders AND Goblin Balloon Brigade. But Lord of Atlantis was blue, which meant easy access to Phantasmal Terrain or Magical Hack, ensuring that your islandwalking fishfolk would be able to stomp your opponent rather easily.

At least Goblin King had [autocard]Mons's Goblin Raiders[/autocard] AND [autocard]Goblin Balloon Brigade[/autocard].  But Lord of Atlantis was blue, which meant easy access to [autocard]Phantasmal Terrain[/autocard] or [autocard]Magical Hack[/autocard], ensuring that your islandwalking fishfolk would be able to stomp your opponent rather easily.

1207: Magical Hack.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1207: Magical Hack.text_parsed: Magical Hack, and its counterpart Sleight of Mind, were best used with the color-hosers that were so prevalent back then. Lifetap and Volcanic Eruption were made that much better when Magical Hack could make them effective against any opponent. You could change your Lord of Atlantis to give all your Merfolk of the Pearl Trident forestwalk. Also, because it didn't say "all instances" at the time, one could use it to allow his Sea Serpent or Island Fish Jasconius to attack a person who controlled Mountains without worrying about his islandhome creature being buried. And you could do all that without ever leaving blue!

1208: Mahamoti Djinn.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1208: Mahamoti Djinn.text_parsed:
Mahamoti Djinn. The creature that every Clone and Vesuvan Doppelganger hoped to copy. The pinnacle of every Revised-era blue deck. Strangely, the Djinn never achieved the popularity or the fame of its biggest adversary, Shivan Dragon. Granted, it lacked the damage-dealing potential of its red rival, but the Djinn could block Sea Serpents, Fire Elementals, Water Elementals, and Demonic Hordes, and survive.

My aunt was actually the first person I knew to get one of these. I remember staring at it in shock for a minute. The biggest flier I owned was Sengir Vampire. I'd heard of Shivan Dragon. I thought I had a pretty good idea of what was what in the Revised set. But here was a 5/6 flier that I'd never seen nor heard about before. And while my initial reaction was jealousy, it was quickly overcome by a sense of wonder at what else was out there that I hadn't seen yet.

1209: Mana Short.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1209: Mana Short.text_parsed:
This was the only card my uncle was missing from the Revised set, and he offered to trade a Shivan Dragon to me or my friends if we managed to "pick the rose" from one of our booster packs. My brother's friend Gregg drew the lucky straw the next week when we all took a trip down to the local Comic Book Store to get a few packs each, and so, because of Mana Short and a trade, he became the first of our little playgroup to own the mighty Shivan Dragon.

None of us at the time had any idea how good Mana Short itself actually was. Even without Stasis or Winter Orb, this could cripple an opponent's tempo. Cast during your opponent's upkeep, and they probably wouldn't be able to play any spells until their next turn.

1218: Psychic Venom.author: Gaussgoat
1218: Psychic Venom.text_parsed:
This a fun little enchantment for Blue that can really add-up. I think it is very playable since its cost is so low... a steal at 1U.

The real beauty of Psychic Venom is that it combos well with a number of other blue spells, all designed to tap lands, etc:

Mana Short - You can't do anything and take damage.
Power Leak - Counter a spell and tap your land
Twiddle - quick flexible hit
Enervate - Cantrip and damage
Drain Power - Setup for the big finisher that kills at the same time

It also works well as a deterrant, forcing people to make tough choices:

Power Leak lose your enchantment or take damage.
Virtually any card with upkeep, etc.

Overall, a fun card.

4/5

1219: Reconstruction.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1219: Reconstruction.text_parsed:
I love the art on this one. Some sort of cyborg skeleton with awesomely creepy long fingers getting pulled back together and reassembled in a blinding flash. Probably the coolest way imaginable to represent this concept. In my opinion, the art really adds to the perceived power of the card. Just picture if the art was some dude tinkering at a work bench. I wouldn't want to play that.

It is also fun, flavorful, simple and can be quite useful in the right deck. You lose card advantage, but it only costs a single mana, allows for great combos and gives you the flexibility to reuse the most effective artifact for the current situation. And the card disadvantage is simple for a blue deck to makeup.

R&D "Balanced" the Color Pie back in the day by doing this, Boil, and there was totally a Green effect that wrecked the tar out of Islands, but I forget it's name.

It was an arms race to see who cast their Color-Specific Godzilla at each other first. :P

"Alpha Eldrazi Blue", "Alpha Eldrazi Red", "Alpha Eldrazi Green"

Cast Alpha Eldrazi (color) only if your opponent is playing that color.
When Alpha Eldrazi enters the battlefield, rape that color.

I don't remember if White and Black really did this as badly. Oh sure, there was Color-Hate in all 5 colors, but it seems Black Knight and White Knight were in general a lot more balanced about this than Animar was.

1234: Water Elemental.author: Gaussgoat
1234: Water Elemental.text_parsed:
Blue's answer to the Fire Elemental back in the day.

This card is hugely underrated. For blue, it is lb for lb one of the absolute best creatures you can get for 5CC. Don't believe me? Do a search of blue creatures with a power of 5, and then look at CC's... Water Elemental is one of the lowest, if not THE lowest, and it lacks the drawbacks of a lot of other creatures.

Some may say this has seen its time, but I think a 5/4 creature in a deck laden with things that give flight and knock blockers out of the way with unsummon has its place.

4/5

1239: Craw Wurm.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1239: Craw Wurm.text_parsed: Once upon a time, Craw Wurm was my biggest Magic creature. My first Magic deck was a 5-color, 60-card Revised Starter deck stripped of rares by my uncle who introduced me to the game. It included a Sea Serpent and a Craw Wurm. But Craw Wurm, with no drawbacks, was obviously the better creature. The first time I bought Magic cards on my own, I bought 2 booster packs of Revised and 2 booster packs of The Dark. I remember being ridiculously excited to find my second Craw Wurm in one of those Revised packs (essentially making my deck TWICE as good). Craw Wurm has become iconic to the game of Magic. At 6/4, Craw Wurm was a beastly common. Only Sea Serpent had any chance against the mighty Wurm in combat. Craw Wurm was the reason many beginning players chose to play green. And with cards like Llanowar Elves and Wild Growth, playing Craw Wurm was pretty easy.
1239: Craw Wurm.text_posted: Once upon a time, Craw Wurm was my biggest Magic creature.  My first Magic deck was a 5-color, 60-card Revised Starter deck stripped of rares by my uncle who introduced me to the game.  It included a Sea Serpent and a Craw Wurm.  But Craw Wurm, with no drawbacks, was obviously the better creature.  The first time I bought Magic cards on my own, I bought 2 booster packs of Revised and 2 booster packs of The Dark.  I remember being ridiculously excited to find my second Craw Wurm in one of those Revised packs (essentially making my deck TWICE as good).  Craw Wurm has become iconic to the game of Magic.  At 6/4, Craw Wurm was a beastly common.  Only [autocard]Sea Serpent[/autocard] had any chance against the mighty Wurm in combat.  Craw Wurm was the reason many beginning players chose to play green.  And with cards like [autocard]Llanowar Elves[/autocard] and Wild Growth, playing [autocard]Craw Wurm[/autocard] was pretty easy.

1239: Craw Wurm.author: land_comment
1239: Craw Wurm.text_parsed: Yeah, I remember the days... Now, people pass up Yavimaya Wurms regularly.
1239: Craw Wurm.text_posted: Yeah, I remember the days... Now, people pass up [autocard]Yavimaya Wurms[/autocard] regularly.

1239: Craw Wurm.author: Gaussgoat
1239: Craw Wurm.text_parsed:
Mirroring the comments of other users, yeah, this dude was BIG back in the day. In an era of 2/2's, 3/3's and banding 1/1's, Craw Wurm was there to dish out some serious pain.

Glad to see it got a sentimental upgrade with Yavimaya Wurm so that new players can get psyched about green face smashing.

Needless to say, hideously overcosted by modern standards. Check out Terra Stomper for a mega 6-drop.

Nostalgic 2.5/5

1240: Crumble.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1240: Crumble.text_parsed: Once upon a time, artifact destruction was the domain of red, then white, then green. Red had Shatterand Shatterstorm. White had Disenchant. Green had this little number. From a standpoint of mana cost, Crumble is clearly the most efficient, but is it worth the life gain you're giving your opponent? Surely an early game Crumble against your opponent's Sol Ring, Ornithopter, Ivory Tower, or Black Vise would be VERY cost effective. But do you really want to give your opponent 4 life in the mid game to destroy his Rod of Ruin?

1241: Desert Twister.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1241: Desert Twister.text_parsed: Six mana is a hefty investment, but this is the ultimate removal card. You can use it to destroy an artifact, an enchantment, a land, a creature - ANYTHING. And it's not white or black (I'm looking at YOU, Vindicate). It's green! Green just doesn't DO creature destruction! But this gem does! If you're running some decent mana acceleration - Llanowar Elves, Wild Growth, Sol Ring, Birds of Paradise, etc. - then do yourself a favor and run a few Desert Twisters alongside your Craw Wurms at the 6 cc slot. So long as your mana base can support them, these cards are simply awesome.

1242: Elvish Archers.text_parsed: At 2 mana, the original green first striker is arguably the best. It was copied as a common twice - as Hornet Cobra and then Land Leeches - at a higher mana cost. Elvish Archers can deal with the plethora of 2 toughness commons in Revised like Pearled Unicorn, Scathe Zombies, Gray Ogre and the like. Its one toughness means that like Savannah Lions, the Elves are particularly susceptible to Rod of Ruin and Prodigal Sorcerer.

1242: Elvish Archers.author: Eved
1242: Elvish Archers.text_parsed:
@Ibn_Shisha
Nice joke

@everyone who doesn't know
The movie 300 was based on the Battle of Thermopylae.
This card's flavor text is referencing a quote made during that battle.
The battle happened over 2,000 years before MTG came out.

1242: Elvish Archers.author: Ibn_Shisha
1242: Elvish Archers.text_parsed:
Interesting thing about the flavor text - this predates 300 by quite some time, one wonders if whoever wrote that particular bit of dialog in 300 was an old-school magic player...

@Eved - How do we know what anyone really said at the Battle of Thermopylae. Herodotus may have used creative license in Histories vol. VII. Most of his information was via word-of-mouth.
1242: Elvish Archers.text_posted:
Interesting thing about the flavor text - this predates 300 by quite some time, one wonders if whoever wrote that particular bit of dialog in 300 was an old-school magic player...

@Eved - How do we know what anyone really said at the Battle of Thermopylae.  Herodotus may have used creative license in [i]Histories vol. VII[/i].  Most of his information was via word-of-mouth.

1242: Elvish Archers.author: Drvst
1242: Elvish Archers.text_parsed:
The flavor text is indeed a reference to Hdt. 7.226.1. "ὡς ἐπεὰν οἱ βάρβαροι ἀπίωσι τὰ τοξεύματα, τὸν ἥλιον ὑπὸ τοῦ πλήθεος τῶν ὀιστῶν ἀποκρύπτουσι: τοσοῦτο πλῆθος αὐτῶν εἶναι. " It is tucked inside a whole lot of indirect discourse.... so it turns out Herodotus heard about this guy named Dieneces who heard from the Trachinians that "When the barbarians shot their arrows, that they hid the sun by the great number of arrows... so large was the number of arrows." Translated by me.
Cool, eh? 5 stars for a Herodotus reference

1243: Fastbond.author: SlackWareWolf
1243: Fastbond.text_parsed:
Fastbond is one of the best cards ever printed. Add Zuran Orb and Crucible of Worlds and you have infinite life and Mana, and add Braingeyser for a first turn win without using any Power9. amazing.

EDIT:

The other guy already mentioned how to do it, but I did have a Sol Ring for this, which speeded up a little bit, but since Sol Ring is restricted in everything it's allowed in, it's hard to get that AND Fastbond in your opening hand, so the Lands work more often, and Sol Ring of course is great.

But anyway, as I said, the other poster already showed how to do this and win a game on turn 0 or 1 without any Power 9 cards.

I built a deck specifically to do this, and it's a type of Vercursion deck that can win on turn 1 without any cards over a certain price. You can of course add the Power 9 to it, which makes it even faster, but not everyone can afford that so I wanted to find a way to win on the first turn without expensive stuff. I did it so I'm proud of that anyway.

1243: Fastbond.author: Cute-Hydra
1243: Fastbond.text_parsed:
When Amulet of Vigor comes out this will enable turn 2 Kills,

Turn 1 Forest: Amulet of Vigor
Turn 2, Tap Forest- Play Fastbond, then play an untapped Simic Growth Chamber returning the forest, then tap the Simic Growth Chamber for 2 mana and then play a Boros Garrison, returning the Growth Chamber, you keep returning in a loop for a cost of 1 life for 2 mana, until you have done it 11times and you have lost 11 life for 22mana at which point you fireball/banefire/disintegrate them to death.

In multiplayer you can do it further with a Dawnglow infusion for more more life to get even more mana, of course you would need different bounce lands but the two above are just examples.

Yay for silly Wizards printing ridiculous cards.

1243: Fastbond.author: Eppek_the_Goblin

Or something good.

Now you have 17 life and got ability to draw 2 cards at the cost of 3 life, meaning you can draw 10. Once you dig up a Zuran Orb or Urza's Armor or Nomad Stadium, you have unlimited mana and unlimited draw, it is gameover there. So 5 card turn1 kill if you got archaeological dig, fastbond, horizon canopy, crystal vein and crucible of worlds. No powernine there.

1244: Fog.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1244: Fog.text_parsed: One of the earliest combat tricks in Magic was putting Lure on a Thicket Basilisk and attacking your opponent. Prior to 4th edition changes, Fog was an effective means to counter such an attack (for one turn anyway). 4th edition cleaned Fog up so-to-speak, removing the clunky "otherwise affect any creature as a result of an attack or block" clause.

Prior to 4th edition changes, Fog was an effective means to counter such an attack (for one turn anyway).  4th edition cleaned Fog up so-to-speak, removing the clunky "otherwise affect any creature as a result of an attack or block" clause.

1245: Force of Nature.author: sweetestsadist
1245: Force of Nature.text_parsed: It's so sad this card is now pretty much obsolete. Force of Nature is the reason green became my favorite color. This guy was in my first set of three boosters I bought. My friend and I taught ourselves to play back in revised and he was jealous of the Island Fish Jasconius I got in my first starter. A couple of weeks later I pulled this guy and I felt like the luckiest card puller alive. Back then, there was no gatherer or spoiler sheets (at least not for the first two teenagers in town that were playing the game.) So opening packs of Magic really felt like magic. Every card was surprising and pulling this card was, to us, the equivalent of pulling a foil Lotus Cobra today. Happy retirement, Force of Will.

1245: Force of Nature.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1245: Force of Nature.text_parsed: My little brother was the first to pull one of these back in the days of Revised, and I don't think I've ever been more jealous of a Magic card. Force of Nature was the biggest, baddest creature in the set, and with Wild Growth and Llanowar Elves, it was almost too easy to play. The upkeep was rough, but could be offset with a Spirit Link. The way the rules worked then, stacking lifelink abilities (via two Spirit Links) meant you could actually GAIN life by not paying the upkeep cost. All by itself, however, Force of Nature was still top dog. It was my brother's Force of Nature that made me make my very first Magic card single - a ratty old Antiquities Colossus of Sardia (in horrible condition) for $9 out of the display case at my local comic book store.

1245: Force of Nature.author: Gaussgoat
1245: Force of Nature.text_parsed:
While there are larger threats out there today, an 8/8 Trampler for 6CC is still a very dangerous creature to drop on the table. The upkeep requirement is stiff, but with green's mana acceleration and the elimination of mana burn, this guy is still relevant.

It is also very easy to make a combo that avoids damage from him, since the loss can be redirected and/or cancelled. Circle of Protection: Green is an obvious and easy answer.

3.5/5

1246: Fungusaur.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1246: Fungusaur.text_parsed: Fungusaur was the card that taught us the importance of turning target restrictions OFF (i.e. Duels of the Planeswalkers). It encouraged us to think outside the box. I actually splashed blue in my revised green deck just so I could use Prodigal Sorcerer on my own Fungusaur to make him ridiculously huge. I also through Flight in there for good measure, and Serendib Efreet (mainly because I wasn't sure whether he was supposed to be blue or green). Rod of Ruin and Pestilence were other effective ways of pumping up your Fungusaur.

1247: Gaea's Liege.author: Gaussgoat
1247: Gaea's Liege.text_parsed:
This guy was always a nightmare for me in the days of Revised. Combine him with forest walking creatures and you've got a serious problem on your hands. He also chips away at your opponent's mana supply, especially with effects that untap him and let him go 2-1 every turn. Instill Energy was always a nice, easy combo.

He is also a nice late-game pull, since he is a massive defensive creature with a built-in Blanchwood Armor.

Another nice bonus is that he isn't, despite appearances, Legendary. Load a few of these guys in your deck, and your opponent is going to have a really bad day with mana sooner than later.

He is obviously a huge target for removal and/or bounce, so try to give him shroud or some kind of cover if you can. Vines of Vastwood is an easy one; Try the Whispersilk Cloak for something more permanent.

4/5

1247: Gaea's Liege.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1247: Gaea's Liege.text_parsed: Gaea's Liege is to green as Evil Presence is to black. Instead of enabling swampwalk, this is a forestwalk enabler. In order to find any decent forestwalkers, you need to leave Revised. Revised only has Shanodin Dryads. But there are good forestwalkers to be found in Magic. The Liege offers more than Evil Presence, of course, in that it is also a very good blocker - and, if given enough time, both a mana neutralizer and powerful attacker.

1248: Giant Growth.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1248: Giant Growth.text_parsed: One of the simplest and most elegant combat tricks, Giant Growth has turned the tides of many Magic: the Gathering battles. The beauty of Giant Growth is its versatility. Has your opponent's Phantom Monster been giving you trouble? Turn your lowly Scryb Sprites into a 4/4 blocker to put an end to that tyranny. Want to save your Llanowar Elves from an opponent's Lightning Bolt? Give it an instant toughness boost! Wall of Bone preventing you from doing the last 2 points of damage needed to finish off a resilient opponent? Hit your trampling War Mammoth with a Giant Growth for the win.

1249: Giant Spider.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1249: Giant Spider.text_parsed: In the days of Revised, if you didn't have access to ***atrice, Giant Spider was your best bet as far as flying defense in any green deck. Slap Regeneration on this eight-legged monstrosity, and you had a blocker that could stop just about anything. Its 4 toughness meant it was out of Lightning Bolt range, and its relatively low attack power kept it from being Terrored very often. The biggest problem with Giant Spider was that it couldn't tangle with the likes of Serra Angel, Air Elemental, or Sengir Vampire (the quintessential flyers of their day) without some sort of help. Fortunately, Giant Growth was usually just one green mana away.

1250: Grizzly Bears.author: GainsBanding
1250: Grizzly Bears.text_parsed:
One of the first creatures I ever cast. Just good, plain old Grizzly Bears like we have on Earth. They told me I was a noob (not that that term existed in 1994) who was not ready to throw dragons and demons around. But they were exciting to send into battle, even if I didn't understand combat math.
I will never accept Runeclaw Bear as a replacement. Grizzlies represent the simplest of creatures for beginners to enter into the game with. Flavor-wise, that is much more important than some nondes.cript magical claws.

1251: Hurricane.author: BonniePrinceCharlie
1251: Hurricane.text_parsed: An oddity of Magic. Green's Earthquake, wildly out of color utilizing direct damage and mass destruction, all at Uncommon. Flyers are normally more mana intensive to cast over their groundwalking brethren, so when they get wiped out by a hurricane, it's typically more damaging in a cost sense to the opponent than Earthquake, yet still, hurricane is UNCOMMON (until 6th edition). The only thing green about it is the targeting of flyers. Also, has a lower-case 'h' to start the word 'hurricane'. Also, same color as Channel.

1251: Hurricane.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1251: Hurricane.text_parsed: Hurricane complements green's aggressive ground attack in so many ways. The most obvious is that it wipes out flyers, which green often has the most trouble with. But with green's ability to get a lead in the early game, with small, efficiently-costed creatures like Grizzly Bears and Elvish Archers, Hurricane often becomes an effective finisher. And while red has Mana Flare to pump out huge Earthquakes and Fireballs, green has Llanowar Elves, Wild Growth, Birds of Paradise, and Channel to pump up its Hurricanes. Be careful with the last two, however. The Birds will be doomed once the wind starts whipping, and you might be doomed too, considering that a Channel-fueled Hurricane will result in you taking loads of damage.

@kriissii: If you pop your Wasteland (and if it is your only remaining land) in response to the land-destruction trigger on Kudzu, then yes, your opponent will have to place it on the only remaining land left on the battlefield, which incidentally belongs to him.

1254: Kudzu.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1254: Kudzu.text_parsed: Slow and ineffective land destruction at its finest. It wasn't like Wizards was tiptoeing around land destruction back then, either. Green had Ice Storm and black had Sinkhole. But Kudzu offered the possibility of infinite land destruction - if you were willing to say goodbye to a few of your own. You could combine this with Dingus Egg, Icy Manipulator, and Mole Worms. Or you could just play it on one of your opponent's lands in the hopes that he or she would never use it. Or you could leave it out of your deck and play something decent.

1256: Lifeforce.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1256: Lifeforce.text_parsed:
Dameon Willich does the art for this and Instill Energy. The art for Lifeforce has a Darwinistic feel to it, whereas the art for Instill Energy has a very Creationist feel (think Sistine Chapel). In Dominaria, there is no debate. Creation and evolution simply co-exist.

While the name "Lifeforce" epitomizes the color green, the card itself doesn't fit the color pie as we understand it today. Green doesn't counter spells. Even the spells of its arch-enemy, black. But this one does just that. In the days of Revised, before shroud or hexproof existed as keywords, green needed some way of protecting its creatures from black's wide array of kill spells. Lifeforce provided just such an option.

1258: Living Artifact.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1258: Living Artifact.text_parsed:
The good news is that it only costs 1 mana. The bad news is that its ability is very weak and that it requires an artifact to be in play to even cast it. If your opponent is playing artifacts, your best bet is to play Living Artifact on one of them, as opposed to one of your own. Your adversary is probably not going to waste a Disenchant on Living Artifact played on one of his own artifacts, but you can bet he'll do what he can to destroy the artifact (and the Living Artifact along with it) if it happens to be played on one of your artifacts.

Relying on your opponent to play artifacts is bad deck design, and casting it on your own artifacts is asking for card disadvantage. Also, you can never actually net gain life with this card unless you have more than one of them in play. Living Artifact is neat, but something like Wooden Sphere is actually more reliable.

1260: Llanowar Elves.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1260: Llanowar Elves.text_parsed: As a powerful common in all the early core sets, this card and this distinctive art was at the heart of so many players' first impressions of Magic. It defined a core ability of green that has been replicated countless times and inspired numerous variations. It also made a statement that this was not your classic Tolkien fantasy world or D&D elf. This world of Magic was wilder, scarier, more alien, darker and stranger than your typical medieval fantasy setting. I remember as a kid I did not like the art. I had never seen a pale, fierce, tattooed, fanged elf with goggles like this. But I grew to love the distinct flavor and originality. This card made you feel that this was a truly original world and you never knew what strange things you might find in each new pack.

1260: Llanowar Elves.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1260: Llanowar Elves.text_parsed: Running these alongside Wild Growths in a pure green deck made it possible to drop a third or fourth turn Craw Wurm or Force of Nature. Early in Magic's history, green established itself as the color of the mana ramp, and Llanowar Elves was the enabler. Green also had Birds of Paradise and Ley Druid, but the Elves had an advantage over the Birds because they could attack for an occasional point of damage, and an advantage over the Druid because they only cost one mana to summon. Finally, it had an advantage over both because it was common, and just about every kid could get his hands on four of them.
1260: Llanowar Elves.text_posted: Running these alongside [autocard]Wild Growth[/autocard]s in a pure green deck made it possible to drop a third or fourth turn [autocard]Craw Wurm[/autocard] or [autocard]Force of Nature[/autocard]. 1261: Lure.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1261: Lure.text_parsed: The first time I saw Lure, I distinctly remember thinking, "Man, what a horrible card. Why would someone want to get their creature blocked?" So I had a few of them in my card box collecting dust. A few months past before I had the misfortune of playing against someone at school who used the age-old Thicket Basilisk/Regeneration/Lure combo. At that point, I distinctly remember thinking, "Oh." Lure was made for the Basilisk. That made sense. Somehow I failed to recognize that Lure is an amazing card for green no matter how you look at it. Back when there were no Overruns and the only trampling creatures anyone had were War Mammoth and maybe a Force of Nature, green had Lure to make sure its Craw Wurms did more than just nibble the heads off of Benalish Heroes. Stick this on your Shanodin Dryads and let the big guys do their thing.

Others came with certain restrictions: Revive for green cards, Nature's Spiral for permanent cards.
And there is also a creature with that cip/etb effect: Eternal Witness, a 2/1 for .

1280: Atog.author: tavaritz
1280: Atog.text_parsed:
Get hold of Revised Rule Book. It states that all cost:+x/+y effects work only to the end of turn.

It also tells what the very usefull and IMHO mistakenly taken out keyword 'bury' means. It means 'destroy without possibility of regeneration'. Much simpler than the whole phrase used today. Using 'bury' WotC could get more flavor text on the cards, but for some obscure(1) reason they don't want to use it.

(1) The reason I've heard is: "There are too many keywords, people cannot remember them." That's BS as they are introducing new keywords all the time and assume that we, the players, can remember what they are. We can do that, so we can also remember what 'bury' means and it would have been even easier if they had keep using it, because it would have been in every set printed.

1280: Atog.author: Baltharn
1280: Atog.text_parsed:
In regards to whether this card ability lasts as a permanent increase versus end of turn, from the official updated rule book:

"611.2a A continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability lasts as long as stated by the spell or ability creating it (such as "until end of turn"). If no duration is stated, it lasts until the end of the game."

I do not see where it says "all cost:+x/+y effects work only to the end of turn."

The way my friends and I play, you can keep feeding the Atog artifacts and the effect stays like a counter until the end of game. this is only for the 3rd edition revised. Please someone tell me where they see otherwise in the rulebook.

The full section 611:

611. Continuous Effects

611.1. A continuous effect modifies characteristics of objects, modifies control of objects, or affects players or the rules of the game, for a fixed or indefinite period.

611.2. A continuous effect may be generated by the resolution of a spell or ability.

611.2a A continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability lasts as long as stated by the spell or ability creating it (such as "until end of turn"). If no duration is stated, it lasts until the end of the game.

1280: Atog.author: Clean_Wererat_2005
1280: Atog.text_parsed:
@ Baltham:

well yes, those are the current rules.

as per tavaritz: "Get hold of Revised Rule Book. It states that all cost:+x/+y effects work only to the end of turn."

For a brief period in 1994 those were the printed rules. Note that Revised versions of Firebreathing and Blessing also do not say until end of turn (and Dragon Whelp, Shivan Dragon and so on).

So by all means, go on playing Atog incorrectly if you like.

1280: Atog.author: Aquillion
1280: Atog.text_parsed: Yeah, back in Revised the rules were that +x/+y abilities lasted until the end of the turn unless the card explicitly stated otherwise.  It was incredibly confusing, and Atog in particular confused people (because at first glance it didn't look like it would be that broken for it to be permanent in the Revised set, where there were almost no 0-cost artifacts.)

1281: Burrowing.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1281: Burrowing.text_parsed: Obviously a very situational card. Not very good unless your opponent is playing red, and if your opponent IS playing red, he'll probably be able to burn away the creature you just gave mountainwalk to. Like all auras, Burrowing runs you the risk of card disadvantage. Even though it only costs a single mana, it doesn't do enough to warrant playing it on one of your creatures. Burrowing could combo nicely with Magical Hack, but that would turn bad card disadvantage into REALLY bad card disadvantage if your creature was subsequently destroyed. It might be better played with Phantasmal Terrain.

1282: Chaoslace.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1282: Chaoslace.text_parsed: There's a lot of neat tricks you can do with Chaoslace, but all are situational, and none are particularly good. Part of the problem with Chaoslace, and all laces for that matter, is that they are the color they turn stuff. If you're playing red, it's rare that you would ever want to turn one of your own cards red - they all ready ARE. And for that matter, why would you want to turn your opponent's card red? The laces are only playable in multi-colored decks. If you're holding a Blue Elemental Blast in your hand, Chaoslace becomes your best friend. If you have a Circle of Protection: Red in play and your opponent is bearing down on you with a Force of Nature, Chaoslace is invaluable. But if you're not playing red color hosers, this doesn't have much appeal.

1283: Disintegrate.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1283: Disintegrate.text_parsed: Before there was Blaze, there were the original sister X-burners - Fireball and Disintegrate. Both are strictly better than Blaze, and both were printed at the common rarity. Disintegrate was particularly effective against pesky regenerators like Drudge Skeletons, but was more often used as a game-ender, dealing damage directly to your opponent. A classic combo of the time used Channel and either Disintegrate or Fireball to turn a small lead into an instant win.
1283: Disintegrate.text_posted: Before there was [autocard]Blaze[/autocard], there were the original sister X-burners - [autocard]Fireball[/autocard] and Disintegrate. 1283: Disintegrate.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1283: Disintegrate.text_parsed: For some reason, this always seemed to play second fiddle to Fireball. People always talked about Channel-Fireball, not Disintegrate. Sure, Fireball could hit multiple targets but I rarely had the mana for that anyway. This card, however, could take out a lot more threats in a time when regeneration was a common ability and there were several common ways to bring cards back from the graveyard. Plus, the art on this card is LOADS better than the original fireball. It truly captures the feeling that you won't be seeing this creature again because there isn't even a corpse left to reanimate!

1284: Dragon Whelp.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1284: Dragon Whelp.text_parsed: When I first started playing Magic in 1994, I had no access to online spoilers or card lists. I had a very limited knowledge of the cards, and it was mostly restricted to the cards I owned. One exception to that was Shivan Dragon. While I didn't own a Shivan, I knew all about it. Every Magic player did. It was THE iconic creature of the time. A card that I did own, however, was Dragon Whelp. A card with an adorable picture, that I quickly learned was one of the most powerful cards I owned. Every time I played Dragon Whelp, I found myself wanting a Shivan Dragon more. If the baby was this good, just imagine how awesome the mommy dragon would be! At first, flying was enough for my Dragon Whelp, but soon my opponent's were playing Phantom Monsters and Serra Angels, and I found that I didn't want my little firebreathing friend to die, so I started using the Whelp with Dwarven Warriors, which turned out to be almost as fun a combo as hurling my Uthden Troll with my Stone Giant.

1286: Dwarven Weaponsmith.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1286: Dwarven Weaponsmith.text_parsed: Dwarven Weaponsmith has an extremely weak ability. It allows you to turn your artifacts into +1/+1 counters. If it worked at instant speed, this would be a decent (if limited) ability. But since you must do it during your upkeep, you can't use it as a combat trick, or to sac an artifact that was all ready headed to the graveyard. There are few artifacts that you'd ever want to sacrifice to the dwarves. Perhaps this could be used effectively in conjunction with The Hive, or it might be a good way to get rid of a pesky Mishra's War Machine. With all that said, the Weaponsmith is a 1/1 with an ability for 2 mana, so not completely unplayable.

1289: Earthquake.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1289: Earthquake.text_parsed: A very efficient and controllable board-sweeper, Earthquake can generate awesome card advantage. The best part about Earthquake is that it's not completely indiscriminate. You can decide how much you want to shake up the board, killing off your opponent's creatures, but leaving your high toughness creatures - like Earth Elemental alive. You can also design your deck around this little gem. Fill your deck with flying creatures like Granite Gargoyle, Goblin Balloon Brigade, and Dragon Whelp who won't feel the effects of the devastating quake, or run creatures with protection from red. Consider protecting yourself from the effects by running Circle of Protection: Red. Make Earthquake even more devastating by running it with Mana Flare, and put the hurt on your opponent's flyers by running Earthbind.

The best part about Earthquake is that it's not completely indiscriminate.  You can decide how much you want to shake up the board, killing off your opponent's creatures, but leaving your high toughness creatures - like [autocard]Earth Elemental[/autocard] alive.  You can also design your deck around this little gem. Consider protecting yourself from the effects by running [autocard]Circle of Protection: Red[/autocard].  Make Earthquake even more devastating by running it with [autocard]Mana Flare[/autocard], and put the hurt on your opponent's flyers by running [autocard]Earthbind[/autocard].

1290: Fire Elemental.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1290: Fire Elemental.text_parsed: At one time, red's premier ground-beater. Fire Elemental and Earth Elemental filled the 5 cc slot in any respectable red deck, and for players who didn't own the mighty Shivan Dragon, this topped out the curve. With its 5/4 power and toughness, Fire Elemental was arguably more useful than Earth Elemental. Fire Elemental was played far more often than blue's Water Elemental, as red had nothing in common to come close to Fire Elemental in terms of size. In the first "theme deck" I ever built (It was called 'Hellfire' and consisted of Fire Elemental, Drudge Skeletons, Wall of Fire, Wall of Bone, etc - Hey, I was 14, lighten up! :P) , this was my big finisher

1291: Fireball.text_parsed: One of the classic X-burners. Fireball was often coupled with Disintegrate and Mana Flare for some huge damage potential. It also worked well with green's Channel. Fireball had the added advantage of allowing you to split its damage between creatures and players as you chose, giving you added flexibility.

Fireball had the added advantage of allowing you to split its damage between creatures and players as you chose, giving you added flexibility.

1292: Firebreathing.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1292: Firebreathing.text_parsed: Once upon a time, only really special creatures had this ability. Nowadays, common creatures are printed with this ability, and it hardly has any effect on the casting cost. In Revised, only the iconic Shivan Dragon had built-in firebreathing. Even Dragon Whelp had a limited form of it. Firebreathing turned any creature into quite the menace. Stick this on your Mons's Goblin Raiders in a pure red deck, and suddenly the goblins aren't so funny any more. Put it on a small creature and then use Dwarven Warriors to make that creature unblockable for added fun. Better still, put it on your Uthden Troll for an extremely deadly blocker that just won't go away.
1292: Firebreathing.text_posted: Once upon a time, only really special creatures had this ability.  Nowadays, common creatures are printed with this ability, and it hardly has any effect on the casting cost.  In Revised, only the iconic [autocard]Shivan Dragon[/autocard] had built-in firebreathing.  Even [autocard]Dragon Whelp[/autocard] had a limited form of it.  Firebreathing turned any creature into quite the menace.  Stick this on your [autocard]Mons's Goblin Raiders[/autocard] in a pure red deck, and suddenly the goblins aren't so funny any more.  Put it on a small creature and then use [autocard]Dwarven Warriors[/autocard] to make that creature unblockable for added fun.  Better still, put it on your [autocard]Uthden Troll[/autocard] for an extremely deadly blocker that just won't go away.

1292: Firebreathing.author: Jannissary

Definitely an outstanding card, one problem. The ruling- 10/4/2004 The Fork card goes to the graveyard when it resolves and leaves the copy on the stack. There is no card representing the copy on the stack.- is wrong.
This judge read as far as "Any one sorcery or instant spell just cast is duplicated.", then made a call off of that. Fork reads "Treat Fork as an exact copy of target spell except that Fork remains red." meaning Fork is that spell. If the spell(i.e. Fork)resolves the spell is cast, there is no phantom card on the stack. Many rulings can be avoided by keeping this in mind involving(e.g.) Guile, Dragon's Claw and the sort, Eyes of the Wisent, ...
1294: Fork.text_posted:
Definitely an outstanding card, one problem. The ruling- 10/4/2004  	The Fork card goes to the graveyard when it resolves and leaves the copy on the stack. There is no card representing the copy on the stack.- is wrong.
This judge read as far as "Any one sorcery or instant spell  just cast is duplicated.", then made a call off of that. Fork reads "Treat  Fork as an exact copy of target spell except that Fork remains red." meaning Fork [i]is[/i] that spell. If the spell(i.e. Fork)resolves the spell is cast, there is no phantom card on the stack. Many rulings can be avoided by keeping this in mind involving(e.g.) [b][autocard]Guile[/autocard][/b], [b][autocard]Dragon's Claw[/autocard][/b] and the sort, [b][autocard]Eyes of the Wisent[/autocard][/b], ...

1294: Fork.author: LG
1294: Fork.text_parsed:
@darkfury: whenever you Fork a Fork, you actually Fork something else; no recursion is possible.
The first Fork is a red copy of, say, a Fireball; the second Fork is cast with the original and Forked Fireballs on the stack, so it can copy either (they are identical up to their controller and set of targets) to become a third Fireball with possibly different targets.
1294: Fork.text_posted:
@darkfury: whenever you Fork a Fork, you actually Fork something else; no recursion is possible.
The first Fork is a red copy of, say, a [autocard]Fireball[/autocard]; the second Fork is cast with the original and Forked Fireballs on the stack, so it can copy either (they are identical up to their controller and set of targets) to become a third Fireball with possibly different targets.

I think I just missed out on most of its potential as a beginning player.

1296: Goblin King.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1296: Goblin King.text_parsed: Goblin King gives viability to Goblin Decks. He gives them a much needed power/toughness boost and decent evasion (although arguably not as good as that granted by Lord of Atlantis). Use with Blood Moon to make your goblins unblockable. It's interesting to look at the changes Goblin King went through during his many years. From Alpha through Unlimited, Goblin King was a 3/3 mountainwalker. Revised cut his power level significantly by making him creature type "lord" instead of a goblin. In 9th, some of his former glory was restored as he once again became a goblin, but now only boosted OTHER goblins. So at least multiple Goblin Kings in play affect each other.

1297: Granite Gargoyle.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1297: Granite Gargoyle.text_parsed: Granite Gargoyle is the perfect example of reverse power creep. For 3 mana, you get a 2/2 flyer that can pump its toughness. Compare to Goblin Sky Raider or Bird Maiden at the same cost. The difference, of course, being that Granite Gargoyle was rare, not common. Still, for a color that isn't known for having lots of options for small to mid-sized flyers, Granite Gargoyle is a great choice. Throw it in a deck with Roc of Kher Ridges, Dragon Whelps, and Earthquakes for ground-shaking fun.

1300: Hurloon Minotaur.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1300: Hurloon Minotaur.text_parsed: For some reason, Hurloon Minotaur managed to elude my grasp for several months when I first started playing Magic. When I first saw one, it was in a casual game at school, and I thought it was some impressive rare. My eyes grew wide as I beheld the woolly white beast my opponent had just played. "What is THAT?" I demanded. "Uh..." my opponent replied incredulously, "a Hurloon Minotaur?" So then I read the card and realized it was only a crappy 2/3. I had Hill Giants bigger than that thing. Why was that a rare? Then I remembered I'd asked myself that same question about Lifelace and Underground Sea. Wizards of the Coast was so retarded. It wasn't until a few months and about a dozen Hurloon Minotaurs later, that I discovered it wasn't rare at all. Or even uncommon, for that matter. I'd just been lucky enough not to get any. But it would still be a while before I'd discover that Underground Sea should never be put in the same sentence as Lifelace.
1300: Hurloon Minotaur.text_posted: For some reason, [autocard]Hurloon Minotaur[/autocard] managed to elude my grasp for several months when I first started playing Magic.  When I first saw one, it was in a casual game at school, and I thought it was some impressive rare.  My eyes grew wide as I beheld the woolly white beast my opponent had just played. "What is THAT?" I demanded.  "Uh..." my opponent replied incredulously, "a Hurloon Minotaur?"  So then I read the card and realized it was only a crappy 2/3.  I had [autocard]Hill Giant[/autocard]s bigger than that thing.  Why was that a rare?  Then I remembered I'd asked myself that same question about [autocard]Lifelace[/autocard] and [autocard]Underground Sea[/autocard].  Wizards of the Coast was so retarded.  It wasn't until a few months and about a dozen Hurloon Minotaurs later, that I discovered it wasn't rare at all.  Or even uncommon, for that matter.  I'd just been lucky enough not to get any.  But it would still be a while before I'd discover that Underground Sea should never be put in the same sentence as Lifelace.

1300: Hurloon Minotaur.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1300: Hurloon Minotaur.text_parsed: High marks for art, flavor text and nostalgia. Unfortunately, rarely played due to not being all that useful. Although he was costed about right for the time, compared to Scathe Zombies and Pearled Unicorn, he just didn't fit in aggressive red decks as well as Balduvian Barbarians. But he was a great card to get in my first starter pack because I remember just staring at the art and reading the flavor text and thinking about what type of amazing new world this was. It provided a few very specific details (the hymns, the tattoos, the carved horns, the misty breath), but also left so much to the imagination (what weapons he used, the terrain, their society, the meaning of the markings, who they fought and why) that it acted like a spark to jump start my imagination. I created a world in my head from these first few cards. The game didn't need to provide tons of detailed characters or a complex plot or spell out every relationship between every faction. They provided a wonderful, mysterious, open setting and let the player fill in the rest. The sense of mystery and possibility of opening cards early in the life of Magic when I was about 13 was just one of those magical moments of youth.

1301: Keldon Warlord.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1301: Keldon Warlord.text_parsed: Keldon Warlord rewards you for playing a creature-heavy deck, so many early goblin decks used Warlords as their big finisher. Until the release of The Dark expansion, there just weren't enough goblins in Magic to make a deck entirely comprised of them. But this guy could certainly pack a punch. The main problem with the Warlord is that there are more reliable options for red at the 4 casting cost slot. In a typical duel, the Warlord isn't going to get much bigger than a 3/3 or a 4/4, and most of the time he'll be even smaller than that. If you're looking for a big red creature, check out Fire Elemental, Earth Elemental, or even Stone Giant. At least with them, you don't have to worry about keeping your Mons's Goblin Raiders alive just to keep them big and fat.

1303: Lightning Bolt.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1303: Lightning Bolt.text_parsed: Excellent by today's standards, Lightning Bolt was even better in the day's of Revised. It saw play in an environment that didn't shy away from burn. Fireball, Disintegrate, Earthquake, and Chain Lightning all helped make "3 to your face" even more deadly. Lightning Bolt also saw a lot of action taking out your opponent's mid-sized creatures. Juggernauts, Phantom Monsters, Hypnotic Specters, Kird Apes, and all manner of knights and bears met their untimely ends thanks to this card.
1303: Lightning Bolt.text_posted: Excellent by today's standards, Lightning Bolt was even better in the day's of Revised.  It saw play in an environment that didn't shy away from burn.  [autocard]Fireball[/autocard], [autocard]Disintegrate[/autocard], [autocard]Earthquake[/autocard], and [autocard]Chain Lightning[/autocard] all helped make "3 to your face" even more deadly.  Lightning Bolt also saw a lot of action taking out your opponent's mid-sized creatures.  [autocard]Juggernaut[/autocard]s, [autocard]Phantom Monster[/autocard]s, [autocard]Hypnotic Specter[/autocard]s, [autocard]Kird Ape[/autocard]s, and all manner of knights and bears met their untimely ends thanks to this card.

1303: Lightning Bolt.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1303: Lightning Bolt.text_parsed:
Obviously one of the best cards in Revised or in any set, for that matter. This card has versatility, power, speed, flavor, you name it. And I appreciate the simplicity and modesty of the art for such a brutal card. No silly face of someone getting hit with it. And it was never without a target. A key consideration for any creature back in the days of Revised and Fourth Editions was whether it could be killed by lightning bolt because every red deck played it. The only thing wrong with this card is that it was played so much.

In my early years of playing, I often wondered if the best deck in Magic might be solely Mountains and Lightning Bolts. Fast mana would help if you had any, but probably wouldn't be needed.

I also love the simplicity of the presentation on this cycle of "one mana for three effect" cards: no flavor text, no clutter, no complex rules. Just simple effects that didn't need to be explained or justified with flavor. Normally, I'm a big fan of good flavor text, but in this case, less is more. The streamlined presentation just fits with the fast, direct nature of the spell. And by not attaching some mage's name or motive to the effect through flavor, it allowed the player to assume more ownership of the spell and apply more imagination to how it was cast and why. And on a card that was played this much, any flavor text would just get old and overdone.

When my friends and I first started playing, our favorite cards were simple. We avoided powerful, but complex cards such as Power Sink or just about anything with tiny font, because we didn't really understand how they worked.

Red has always been my favorite color ever since I started playing Magic in Revised and this spell may be a big reason why. I wonder if designers today could resist the urge to crowd this card with more "action-packed" art or flavor text from their favorite planeswalker.

1304: Magnetic Mountain.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1304: Magnetic Mountain.text_parsed: For the cost of a Hurloon Minotaur, Magnetic Mountain puts a serious hurt on any creature-based blue decks. But aside from the occasional Merfolk of the Pearl Trident / Lord of Atlantis combo, blue weenie decks were virtually unheard of until Fallen Empires. If blue played with any creatures at all, they were strong fliers like Phantom Monster, Air Elemental, and Mahamotti Djinn, or huge fatties like Sea Serpent and Island Fish Jasconius. Usually, they weren't playing these creatures by the truckload, so the Paralyze effect of Magnetic Mountain was somewhat easy to overcome. Magnetic Mountain would have been made much better if it were directed at white, which relied heavily on weenie tactics, instead of blue.

It suffers from the same drawback as Howling Mine, however, by benefiting your opponent before it benefits you. With such a powerful ability as doubling the mana produced by lands, giving your adversary this edge can be quite dangerous. With that said, the very fact that this is red makes it worth playing. No color is as dangerous when boatloads of mana are floating around.

1306: Manabarbs.author: Gabriel422
1306: Manabarbs.text_parsed:
It really killed Jund (what were they gonna do, Bituminous Blast something?) and would probably hurt the Primeval Titan decks today if it were to stay.

Creates a fun little mini-game of who's gonna get down to 1 first and be stranded there. Burn decks have an edge, as well as decks with artifact / elf mana sources, and more importantly decks with low average cmc. Who's the winner is also a function of the life totals when you put this down. Describing the function and probability trends would be way too complicated, so let's just say Manabarbs creates many funny situations that no other cards can.

1306: Manabarbs.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1306: Manabarbs.text_parsed:
Manabarbs did what Armageddon Clock tried to do: Put the game on a clock. More than any other card from Revised, with perhaps the exception of Pestilence, Manabarbs sped up the game. This enchantment hurts everyone, but there are ways around it. Llanowar Elves, Birds of Paradise, Sol Ring, and to a lesser extent Wild Growth can all help you get mana without having to tap (as many) lands. And while Circle of Protection: Red and Guardian Angels can't help you, cards like Samite Healer, Healing Salve, Reverse Damage, and Simulacrum can all buy you some extra time.
But Gaussgoat is right about the main strength of this card, which is to make burn decks faster. While there may be several ways to lessen the damage you're taking from the Barbs, your best bet is to just deal damage to your opponent more efficiently than he can deal damage to you. This means Lightning Bolts and Kird Apes.

1309: Orcish Artillery.author: The_Riddle_of_Steel
1309: Orcish Artillery.text_parsed: Probably one of the most useful orcs ever printed, which I know isn't saying much. The trade off seems severe, but the ability to inflict two points of damage for only a tap is fantastically useful. And when you are on the offensive from the start, as most aggressive red decks were, you typically had the early life advantage needed to use the ability. This card was a staple in early Sligh decks. I loved that even moderately powerful cards used to have drawbacks that required more skill to play than just throwing down an endless supply of awesome creatures and attacking.

Tapping for mana cannot be responded to. So when they say 'done', you announce that you'll tap all your lands for mana. They cannot do anything else than tap lands for mana before their turn ends.

1312: Red Elemental Blast.author: tavaritz
1312: Red Elemental Blast.text_parsed:
This was worse than Pyroblast. You couldn't use this against non-blue spells even if you had Thoughtlace, because this couldn't target non-blue spells and after Toughtlace has resolved it was too late to counter the spell. Pyroblast on the other hand could target non-blue spells and thus you could cast pyroblast on green spell, Thoughtlace the spell to blue and Pyroblast would counter it.

Now with no interrupts anymore it's just the same.

4/5

It certainly has it's uses, not in Mono Red Aggro certainly but it's an awful lot to get around for RR1

As for the Color Pie, when this one was dreamed up Richard Garfield and friends were still running Wizards out of a rented basement, much less worrying about how this would fit in with the 20th expansion set.

Remember when this one was dreamed up Lightning Bolt, Fireball and Disintegrate were all very readily available, and a common Red strategy was to sit behind a wall of stone and burn your opponent

Respect it for being a classic even if it doesn't fit modern decks very well

1328: Armageddon.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1328: Armageddon.text_parsed: Armageddon is simple, elegant, and extremely powerful. For four mana, you can clear the board of all lands. This destroys your lands as well as your opponents', but you have the element of surprise on your side. If you play Armageddon in your deck, be sure to keep a few lands in your hand so that you'll be able to replenish your mana supply after the day of reckoning is over. Also, there are a few cards that can really help out your cause. Groundskeeper and Crucible of Worlds can help get your lands back quickly, and if you play Armageddon in combination with Dingus Egg and Reverse Polarity, you can put the hurt on your opponent while gaining a ton of life.

1329: Balance.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1329: Balance.text_parsed: Balance is one of the best white cards of all time.  On the surface, Balance appears to be the ultimate equalizer.  But white's primary strength is its enchantments, and Balance leaves those alone.  It also doesn't touch artifacts.  This means it is relatively easy to tailor a deck around Balance.  The real strength of the card, however, is its ability to destroy land.  Balance is a centerpiece in many White Weenie decks, because those decks rarely play more than two or three lands at a time.  Your opponent will not be able to cast best spells when landlocked by Balance.

1329: Balance.author: Aaron_Forsythe
1329: Balance.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #56, 1/12/11

There are a few patently absurd things going on with the card Balance.

1) The card itself. Few cards in the history of Magic are this powerful. It is banned in Legacy and restricted in Vintage (granted, it isn’t a big player in Vintage, mostly because it is hard to predict how most decks are going to play out with regard to lands, creatures, and cards in hand). But just try playing it in a game using otherwise “normal” cards--it is a complete and utter backbreaker for only two mana.

2) The fact that it took players so long to figure out how good it was. Developer Erik Lauer, genius that he is, understood the power of Balance almost immediately back in the Alpha-Beta days (play Moxes, play Jayemdae Tome, Balance down to nothing), but in general the community didn’t grasp how broken this card was for at least a couple of years.

3) The card was reprinted multiple times, through Fourth Edition. Either Wizards didn’t understand just like players didn’t understand it, or they did and wanted to keep printing it until it was proven broken.

To point number 2, I vividly remember the day Balance was restricted (along with Fork) in April 1995, as this crazy dude Darryl Markowitz that used to play at the University of Pittsburgh Student Union was running around screaming about it. “The card is totally fair! It just makes things even! It’s even called ‘Balance!’ That’s just ridiculous!” Of course, Darryl was typically balancing multiplayer games down to zero creatures and zero cards, often after sacrificing Rukh Egg to Diamond Valley. Let me tell you, it was hard to beat decks with four Balances, even in multiplayer.

It’s possible that we could print a card with this effect again, although the playtesting would start with a cost something like .

1329: Balance.author: willpell
1329: Balance.text_parsed: I am very sad about this card.  It should have been a perfect concept, but the ease with which it can be broken utterly ruins it.  I want the name "Balance" back to use on a card that is just this strong but never in an unfair way, one that cannot be cheated to give its caster an advantage but which does counteract even the greatest advantage of his opponent.  The fact that it could be broken with Moxes is hardly proof of anything, but I'd rather lose Moxes and keep this (which is what the Revised and 4th Edition designers did).  However, cards like Rukh Egg and Diamond Valley are fun, so they demonstrate why this execution of the effect couldn't work.  If you replaced "sacrifice" with "exile" and made a few similar tweaks, you could bring this card back as a two-mana stop sign against rush decks, and I'd be very happy.

However, cards like Rukh Egg and Diamond Valley are fun, so they demonstrate why this execution of the effect couldn't work.  If you replaced "sacrifice" with "exile" and made a few similar tweaks, you could bring this card back as a two-mana stop sign against rush decks, and I'd be very happy.

1329: Balance.author: Cheza
1329: Balance.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:
I love Balance as this card proves that R&D doesn't understand the meaning of balance or the (un)balancing nature of Wrath of God.

Destruction is never fair, especially when it includes lands as well, since usually you pay to play a creature. Therefore, you've earned it and there is nothing inbalanced about it. Likewise, if a weenie deck with a few lands plays against a fattie deck with many lands, it's fair that the weenie deck will have less lands and hand cards, but more (weaker) creatures.

Therefore, if someone plays a Balance or Wrath of God, the only thing he wants to achieve is an inbalance in his favor. First of all, because you decide when to play a creature and when to cast a Wrath of God (f.e. to gain card advantage when you have casted fewer creature spells). Second, you plan your deck by "wasting" a card slot for a Balance. So you hope that this card would acieve a goal.

So neither a Wrath of God, nor a Balance is an act of balance. The latter might feel a bit more balancing, since it includes hand cards, but enchantments and artifacts are ignored and that's the point where the problems come from. A combo deck or counterspell deck has nothing to lose when adding this card.

The funniest point however is that I pray since my registration that white should have less destruction spells and more bounce effects. If you compare Evacuation and Day of Judgment, which one feels more balancing, which one could be abused more and which one feels more white flavored (peaceful)?

So once R&D would recognize this and really choose to do this color-shift, you'll see that an Upheaval is a better balance than the version, Aaron suggested.

(And this would bring us to a mono-white Worldpurge and a white Time Reversal). I still have hope.

1329: Balance.author: DarthParallax
1329: Balance.text_parsed:
I'm slightly surprised that Revised is the highest rated print of Balance ever. I would have expected Beta or Alpha to get that, or From the Vault maybe.

All that said, little can be said about Balance not in Aaron_Forsythe's comment or the mini-article in From the Vault: Exiled.

If you value cards as a collector AND player, then I'd say there are a good number of $20 cards I'd trade for a Balance, even the reprinted versions that actually go for much less.

I don't totally like how expensive the Beta and Alpha cards just hard-SPIKE with regard to economics, but even so, if I could get an Alpha or Beta Balance for $50, I would have to assume I was at one of those AMAZING garage sales you hear about that you never find. :P

If you like playing with historical decks (using different banned lists from different eras), then investing in 4 Balances and 4 Necropotences is an AWESOME start to a Weissman Deck. I think that would be a great way to run Archenemy Games: Let the Archenemy use different Banned/Restricted Lists from the Heroes.

1330: Benalish Hero.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1330: Benalish Hero.text_parsed: Benalish Hero is a no-frills bander. Her 1 toughness means the damage distribution portion of banding will more than likely turn her into fodder. Unlike Mesa Pegasus, Benalish Hero doesn't offer any extras. As banders go, she is as vanilla as they come. With Castle or Crusade in play, Benalish Hero becomes a respectable blocker. She rarely adds much pop to an attacking band, but if you consider how banding works, she effectively gives an attacking creature +1 to its power and reduces all damage it would normally take to 0. For 1 white mana, this isn't bad.

1333: Blue Ward.author: car2n
1333: Blue Ward.text_parsed: The pop-art (yet neo-minimalist) etchings of Blue Ward,  liegemen to the Pollackian legacy, question its own raison d'etre. Is it visual tropes? Is it self-conscious (self-mocking/self-loathing) po-mo nombrilisme? Or is it simply (and solely) a stochastic snapshot sans lexical basis? The color ward cycle can best be examined as artistic interventions against the oppressive humor archetype, whereas the unappealingly desperate musings of Dan Frazier's eponymous series are truly indebted to Jenny Holzer’s oeuvre. Or, as Baudrillard and Guillaume so succinctly state, "What is produced with the romantic turn…is…the…play of…masculine hysteria…of …sexual paradigms that once again must be reinserted in the more general and universal context of a change in the paradigms of otherness."

1334: Castle.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1334: Castle.text_parsed: Back in the days of Revised, when Castle only worked on your blocking creatures, white players would often amass large armies and try to outlast their opponents. With Circles of Protection and banding available to white, along with lots of other defensive spells (such as Island Sanctuary) running an opponent out of cards in casual play was not unheard of. And no mill was even required. Nowardays, Castle is better, and works well with white's many creatures with vigilance.

1335: Circle of Protection: Black.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1335: Circle of Protection: Black.text_parsed: Circle of Protection: Black is definitely one of the more useful Circles as it protects you from black's Drain Life as well as its beaters - Frozen Shade, Sengir Vampire, and Hypnotic Specter. It can also protect you from the annoying Pestilence (though with today's rules, its not a combo that can be easily abused). Back in Revised, you could "batch" pumpable abilities like Fire Breathing, Frozen Shade, and Pestilence. In the case of Pestilence, this meant you could pay "BBBBB" all at once and do five damage to all creatures and players, then pay "1" and protect yourself from the damage via Circle of Protection: Black. Now, you would have to pay 1 for each point of damage you inflicted with Pestilence.

1335: Circle of Protection: Black.author: tavaritz
1335: Circle of Protection: Black.text_parsed:
"Can be used even when there is no damage to prevent. It prevents the next damage (if any) from the source this turn."

Don't understand this ruling at all. I thought that there is no damage prevention anymore and reading the full rules confirms that. Today you have to anticipate the damage and pre-emptively put a damage prevention in effect.

It's easy if we talk about spell stack. You play a Drain Life targetting me and in response I activate my COP: Black. My damage prevention anticipation resolves and waits for the next black damage which, if the Drain Life resolves next, is the Drain Life and It will not damage me.

But it's totally different thing with combat. You attack me with your War Mammoth and I want to kill him. So I block it with my three Drudge Skeletons. Let's say that I have three untapped swamps and Circle of Protection: Green. Under old rules you stated how you distribute your damage and I responded with damage prevention and regenerations. So if you hit one skeleton with all three I regenerate the skeleton and prevent the damage from me, if you take two skeletons, I regenerate them and prevent the one damage and if you take all the skeletons , I regenerate them all.

So no damage to me and three skeletons alive.

Under the new rules I have to anticipate how you'll be distributing the damage. So I can regenerate all skeletons and have no mana to prevent your trample damage, so you'll hit only one skeleton and I suffer 2 points of damage. If on the other hand I regenerate two skeletons and put a damage prevention for green effect floating, you can hit the skeleton wich isn't regenerated and it'll die.

So I'm down two life or one skeletons.

This was improvment in the rules?

1335: Circle of Protection: Black.author: NeedADispenserHere
1335: Circle of Protection: Black.text_parsed:
@tavaritz

If you block a war mammoth with three Drudge Skeletons, your opponent must assign lethal damage to each one before assigning damage to you due to trample. So your opponent has to assign one damage to each skeleton. You pay one mana to regenerate each one. No damage can be dealt to you. All of your skeletons live. The elephant dies. I don't see a problem.

1340: Conversion.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1340: Conversion.text_parsed: Conversion is a mean card. Denying your opponent access to red mana by turning his Mountains into Plains is just cruel. Use Magical Hack in combination with Conversion to hose ANY color except for white. Once the combo is in place, if your opponent doesn't have Birds of Paradise or (LOL) Celestial Prism, its unlikely he'll be able to cast any spell to get rid of it. Pure red mages have been known to sideboard a playset of Disenchants into their deck to deal with Conversions - or alternately, play Sunglasses of Urza. Players who played both red and white sometimes played Conversion AND Sunglasses of Urza to turn all of their lands into Plateaus. The upkeep of Conversion made this a bit unwieldy.

1342: Death Ward.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1342: Death Ward.text_parsed: White has always been known for its defensive combat tricks, and Death Ward was one of the first such tools in white's arsenal. A couple of Death Wards on your Veteran Bodyguard could be extremely frustrating to an aggressive opponent. White always had more intimidating instants (Righteousness, Reverse Damage, Eye for an Eye), and even at the common rarity it was more often passed up for Healing Salve, but not a bad card by any means.

1343: Disenchant.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1343: Disenchant.text_parsed: Disenchant is one of the best white removal cards, and made white control a very viable game strategy. In the early days of White Weenie, decks were less aggro and more control based - relying on cards like Swords to Plowshares, Disenchant, Balance, and Wrath of God to keep the board clear. Disenchant was more versatile than Shatter or Crumble, being able to also destroy enchantments, at virtually no extra cost.

1344: Eye for an Eye.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1344: Eye for an Eye.text_parsed: In Magic's early days, biblical references were fairly common, and they usually appeared in white. Eye for an Eye exemplifies the darker side of white. There is a fine line between justice and revenge, and Eye for an Eye blurs that line. White usually takes out its revenge on creatures (Vengeance), but this is a rare example of a white card that goes right for the opponent's life total.

1345: Farmstead.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1345: Farmstead.text_parsed: Repeating life gain wasn't something Magic offered back in the early days. Life gain was usually either a one time effect (Stream of Life or Healing Salve), triggered (via Throne of Bone or Soul Net), or difficult to get due to mana cost or upkeep (El-Hajjaj, Farmstead, Living Artifact.) Farmstead, though terrible by today's standards, fit the mold back then.

1346: Green Ward.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1346: Green Ward.text_parsed: Green doesn't have much that targets creatures directly, but Green Ward can protect your best creature from Desert Twister, or prevent your Mesa Pegasus from dying to Hurricane. Unlike some of the other Wards, Green Ward is probably best used on a creature with banding, as most of green's threats come in the form of creatures. Unfortunately, protection from green does nothing to prevent you from being stomped by tramplers. In Dingo's example above, a Palace Guard blocking a bunch of green tramplers would only prevent you from taking 4 damage. Any damage beyond lethal damage would be assigned to you.

1347: Guardian Angel.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1347: Guardian Angel.text_parsed: A versatile card, but one that doesn't perform any single function particularly well. You can use it to prevent damage to a player, but that means you have to leave mana untapped and cast it on your opponent's terms, as opposed to say Stream of Life which gains you life immediately when you have the available mana. The other function is to prevent damage to a creature. Again, this function of the card was made obsolete early in Magic's history with the printing of Indestructible Aura, as Mr. Redhatter pointed out.
