1349: Holy Armor.author: Eppek_the_Goblin
1349: Holy Armor.text_parsed: Fourth edition cleaned up the wording on a lot of auras, though Holy Armor never caused that much confusion. It was simply understood that the pumpable bonuses provided by the Armor were temporary, much like the bonuses provided by Firebreathing or Atog's ability. Back then, if it didn't say "permanently," you had to assume it wasn't. Then again, the +0/+2 bonus provided by the Armor is permanent, and it doesn't mention that. As I read the card now, it seems way more confusing than it ever did back in 1994. WotC's rigid wording has killed my ability to reason deductively!
1349: Holy Armor.text_posted: Fourth edition cleaned up the wording on a lot of auras, though Holy Armor never caused that much confusion.  It was simply understood that the pumpable bonuses provided by the Armor were temporary, much like the bonuses provided by [autocard]Firebreathing[/autocard] or [autocard]Atog[/autocard]'s ability.  Back then, if it didn't say "permanently," you had to assume it wasn't.  Then again, the +0/+2 bonus provided by the Armor [i]is[/i] permanent, and it doesn't mention that.  As I read the card now, it seems way more confusing than it ever did back in 1994.  WotC's rigid wording has killed my ability to reason deductively!

1363: Righteousness.author: Burningsickle
1363: Righteousness.text_parsed:
There is better removal/ defense, but this has 3 applicable purposes ordinary removal does NOT.
1. Intentionally having a creature block, and live, against a fatty because you gain benefits specifically when you block.
2. Hexproof (duh).
3. It is simply much more satisfying watching an epic wurm get destroyed by, say, birds of paradise. anyone can be terminated, but it takes a very special kind of wurm to die to a bird.

1366: Serra Angel.author: humor_love
1366: Serra Angel.text_parsed:
gasimakos1 posed an interesting thought: is this the best old-school creature? That person said he/she'd vote for Hypnotic Specter. I think you have to throw Sengir Vampire into the pool of candidates. Maybe Shivan Dragon and Mahamoti Djinn deserve spots, as well. Notice they're all Flying. Notice, too, that, despite green being the 'creature color', I haven't mentioned any creatures for it. Two green creatures that might deserve mention would be Elvish Archers (which would suggest mention of Savannah Lions) and Craw Giant (who was released in '94 in Legends and in '95 in Chronicles - around the time of Revised and 4th).

Anyway, interesting thought. I think that, as the original poster suggested, either Serra Angel or Hypnotic Specter would receive the most votes in such a poll ... and probably Serra Angel. Whether or not she's actually, mechanically, the best creature in early Magic, she's arguably the most iconic creature of early Magic. That is, she's the most well-known and most-respected, on the whole ... and was probably the most-played.

1367: Swords to Plowshares.author: Olliemancer
1367: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed: The best spot removal I've ever seen and played with.  Actually I don't remember not playing white (mainly for these, Balance and Disenchant) and not miss this card.  It has been in every deck I made with white.  So good.  For one mana, at instant, get rid of a creature permanently.  Yeah it's screwed by shroud and protection, but so can be said of any spot removal...  and who cares about the opponent gaining life when you can get rid of an indestructible creature, a regenerating one, or an annoying one that keeps coming back from the graveyard for a reason or another, for one single mana?  5 stars as a spot removal.  AND if you're really stuck in a bad position, you could target your own creature to gain life and get around a dangereous situation.

1368: Veteran Bodyguard.author: Winterhawk200
1368: Veteran Bodyguard.text_parsed:
I wonder how the new Infect mechanic would work with this guy in play. since damage done to a player with infect is done with poison counters and damage to creatures is done with -1/-1 counters. I have three thoughts on this. first thought is that the redirected damage would be dealt to the bodyguard in the form of -1/-1 counters. second thought is that the damage done to the player is actual poison counters so the poison counters would be transferred to the bodyguard since the creature with infect is damaging the player and not damaging the bodyguard, the damage itself is just redirected to the bodyguard. but since their are not actual rules about when a creature has poison counters on it that I know of it would not be effected by them. The third thought would be that the redirected damage would be just that, normal damage to the bodyguard and would not be in the form of a counter at all. unless of course you gave the bodyguard himself infect with and aura or equipment somehow.
I think that it would most likely be done in the form of -1/-1 counters but it has me wondering.

1384: Underground Sea.author: murphy13
1384: Underground Sea.text_parsed:
This is the only site that I have found where everything matches what I have for this card; artist, version and ***. Here is the rub ... I got this and several other "revised" and "unlimited" cards at GenCon, MECCA in Aug of 1993 where and when they were given to me but I know that they were not for sale until April, 1994. I know I have the right year because Wizards only had 3 or 4 small booths, not the "half arena" they had thereafter, the year MidiMaze refused to work, Dactyl VR came out and BattleTech pods made their debut at a "buck a minute".

The cards were given to me by a Wizards Rep (wish I could remember the guys name) and promoted as a "new card game that I had to try out with my friends" and "will be the best thing since D & D was invented".

Question?? Does this add value to the cards or just add value for me?? Our family has fallen on some hard times and as much as I know I will regret it, we are considering selling this and others such as Mox Jet, Time Vault,etc..

Murph

1384: Underground Sea.author: Doaj
1384: Underground Sea.text_parsed: Is your Tabernacle PSA graded like his Underground Sea? Frankly, Underground Sea s the most expensive of the ABUR dual lands, with good condition Underground Sea being worth about $155 a piece. PSA graded ups the value considerably, and while Tabernacle is definitely in the ballpark of two Revised Edition Underground Seas, I think there's less demand for PSA graded Tabernacles, which at the very least makes a comparison kore difficult. All in all, if your Tabernacle is in good enough condition for 8-10 then I'd say it's fair. If it's lower, then your friend is right. It's a lot easier to move an Underground Sea at the price you want than it is to move a Tabernacle.
1384: Underground Sea.text_posted: Is your Tabernacle PSA graded like his Underground Sea? 1387: Forest.text_posted: This is my mom's favorite version of the Revised art Forests.  She likes the flowery path.  I traded her all my flowery path Forests (about six of them) for her two [autocard]Frozen Shade[/autocard]s when I was making my very first pure black deck.

1387: Forest.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
1387: Forest.text_parsed:
@Eppek: Haha, thanks for sharing your story! I've seen another part of it on Demonic Hordes - having family members who will play with you is very cool. =)

I have to back up your mother's tastes, as well. This art is charming, and I don't say that in any belittling sense! It actually does evoke fairytale forests... big old trees, lots of flowers and plants, and an inviting path leading you deeper into it.
1387: Forest.text_posted:
@Eppek: Haha, thanks for sharing your story!  I've seen another part of it on [autocard multiverseid="1154"]Demonic Hordes[/autocard] - having family members who will play with you is very cool.  =)  

I have to back up your mother's tastes, as well.  This art is charming, and I don't say that in any belittling sense!  It actually does evoke fairytale forests... big old trees, lots of flowers and plants, and an inviting path leading you deeper into it.
